awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Optimizing Trauma Care Network Design
awd_abstract_narration:
This award advances the national health by supporting research that will improve trauma care network design.  Trauma is a leading cause  of death in younger populations.  Trauma care networks include trauma centers, staffed and equipped round the clock to treat the most severely injured cases, community hospitals, equipped to stabilize and transport patients to appropriate trauma centers, and air/ground transport services.  The trauma care network should ensure that severely injured patients receive the right care in the right amount of time, but maldistribution of trauma care facilities can result in undertreatment of severely injured patients as well as expensive overtreatment of less-severely injured patients.  This project will facilitate coordinated network design between state agencies and hospital networks, two key stakeholders in the trauma care system. It will enable trauma policy makers to quantitatively benchmark trauma care regionally and nationally in terms of triage errors and costs.  The research team will collaborate with state officials, hospitals, and emergency care providers to validate the network optimization methods.  The award will support graduate student research and provide experiential learning opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students in operations research related to healthcare policy and management.  Research findings will be widely distributed to both the academic and practitioner communities. 

Innovative optimization methods to coordinate the bilevel decision making process for trauma center location are developed in this project.  The research frames the trauma network design problem as a bilevel biobjective optimization problem to capture the hierarchical interaction between the upper level (regional authority) decisions involving subsidy allocation to improve social wellbeing and minimize public spending, and lower level (hospital networks) decisions involving upgrade or downgrade to maximize revenue. Novel techniques for cross-decomposition to bound the combinatorial lower level problem and adaptive scalarization to approximate the entire Pareto set of nonlinear nonconvex multiobjective bilevel programs will enable efficient problem solution. Robustness will be evaluated in response to spatial variations in on-scene decisions, and temporal deviations in projected trauma demand and transport resource availability. New surrogate modeling-based algorithms will help solve the resultant maximal parameter subspace identification problem. Data from two states will be used to validate the approach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This is a collaborative project with Dr. Nan Kong at Purdue University (CMMI #1761022). This award helped advance the national health by supporting research that will improve trauma care network design. Trauma care networks include trauma centers (staffed and equipped round the clock to treat the most severely injured cases), community hospitals (equipped to stabilize and transport patients to appropriate trauma centers), and air/ground transport services.

Given that trauma injuries have a huge health and economic burden to our lives and the society, the outcomes of this research expected to have far-reaching impact. Our optimization models would be the first ever decision-making tools that state trauma divisions can use to collaborate with local hospital systems in evaluating and redesigning their trauma network. Because our approach is general enough to be adopted by any state, it will touch upon the lives of every US citizen.

Our approach provided a quantitative, prescriptive-in-nature, evidence to several laws and legislation that are currently being reviewed and updated in many states. Besides academic outlets, wide dissemination of our work via guest lectures at leading US universities and research reports made available through the state trauma websites of OH and IN were pursued to increase awareness among general public on the use of IE/OR tools for solving problems critical to our society.

Reserach Contributions: To the IE/OR discipline, our research extended the area of location science in two ways. First, we incorporated patient safety as a metric in the location models. To keep the models realistic, we incorporated several details about emergency response for trauma patients, which included EMS decision making process and access times. All of these features have never been studied together, and also lend the models very hard to be solved using state-of-the-art approaches. We, therefore, proposed efficient heuristic algorithms and implemented them in parallel to exploit multi-processor capabilities in modern computers. Second, this research paved path for approaches for value co-creation for both the welfare-seeking government and profit-seeking hospital systems. The corresponding solution approaches under development will lay foundation for solving such complex, yet realistic, models. Additional benefits of extending the boundaries of bilevel optimization along with incorporation of realism in these models were realized.

For the healthcare systems engineering discipline, this project introduced a new problem that focuses explicitly on patient safety via mistriage rates. The single objective (government problem), in and by itself, is fairly novel as it captures under- and over-triage rates in a single model and extends previous rudimentary models into a comprehensive optimization and analysis setting. Our models can serve as a benchmark to American College of Surgeons (ACS) recommended tools (e.g., NBATS) and help evaluate the performance of existing trauma systems. Our models are expected to serve as foundational work for generalization to other trauma systems and also similar problems in other domains (e.g., network of primary care providers, electronic consults, long-term care, and rehabilitation centers).

The discipline of emergency medicine, especially trauma care delivery, will also benefit through this work. The current approaches for trauma network design across the states in the US are very arbitrary. There are no set procedures or policies that regulate where trauma centers should be located. Also, the ACS recommended NBATS tool has been shown to be limited in its ability to identify the number of trauma centers, let alone their location and the subsidy effect. Considering this major limitation in existing approaches, we proposed stand-alone patient-safety focused models and also bi-objective safety-subsidy models in an optimization framework. In that sense, our proposed models have the potential to positively impact this decision-making process through optimization-based, GIS-enabled, subsidized trauma network design approach that will also serve as a benchmark to existing approaches and tools. 

Student Training: This grant has partially supported 4 graduate and several undergraduate students in Industrial and Systems Engineering, and students in Computer Science over the last 4 years. These students had conveyed to me several times their enthusiasm towards the project goals. While a majority of IE/OR research is optimization or algorithm based, this particular project had two additional aspects, the transdisciplinary concepts and real-world application areas. The engineering students were actively involved in every discussion related to data analysis, model development, solution approach, and testing thus far. They experienced first-hand the relevance of the complex analytical and computational modeling that is sometimes required to address real-world challenges; right from domain understanding, decision making process of EMS providers on the field and trauma directors at the state-level, real-world constraints, and the feedback we receive on our findings from these decision makers.
